awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Plasma Heating and Energy Partition in Flares and Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs)
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar eruptions, in the form of flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs), are violent explosions in the Sun's atmosphere that propel millions of tons of hot plasma into interplanetary space.  They are the largest energy-release events in the solar system and the main driver of space weather disturbances at Earth.  When directed towards the Earth, they can adversely affect human endeavors such as air traffic communications, power grids, and satellites, and be hazardous to astronauts traveling in space.  It is therefore important to understand the physics behind these powerful events.  It is widely accepted that the sudden and violent reconfiguration of magnetic fields is the main process that enables the release of energy in solar eruptions.  However, the details of the conversion of magnetic energy into heating and plasma motion are not well understood.  In this three-year project, state-of-the-art computer simulations together with satellite observations will be employed to make progress on this important problem, by modeling and systematically investigating energy transfer and plasma heating in flares and CMEs.  The project will support the dissertation research of a PhD student and thus foster the educational goals of the NSF.

This three-year project will employ sophisticated magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) numerical simulations to model solar eruptions (for both idealized and observed cases).  The simulation results will be used to identify the physical mechanisms responsible for energy conversion and plasma heating during eruptions and to quantify their respective contributions.  These numerical investigations will be complemented with detailed analysis of high-cadence and high-resolution observations from current spacecraft, using well-developed analysis tools for deriving thermal information from observational data.  This project aims to answer several open questions about solar eruptions.  First of all, it will examine the physical mechanisms that heat plasma during the impulsive phase of solar flares and quantify the energy partition in this phase.  Secondly, it will explore the physical mechanisms responsible for heating plasma in the region of the current sheet in the late phase of solar flares.  Thirdly, it will investigate how the recently discovered "hot plasma channels" are formed and heated to temperatures of more than 10 million degrees Kelvin in the early stages of an eruption.  Finally, it will examine how erupting plasma is heated and evolves during its propagation within a CME.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this project was to advance our understanding of the energy-transfer mechanisms that occur during solar flares. The latter manifest as a localized, sudden increase of Extreme Ultraviolet (EUV) and X-ray emission from the corona (the outer solar atmosphere), which lasts from minutes to hours. Solar flares are the largest energy conversion processes in the solar system, and often associated with the eruption of a prominence and a coronal mass ejection (CME). Prominences are dense and cold plasma structures in the hot corona, while CMEs are large expulsions of magnetized plasma from the corona into interplanetary space and the main driver of space weather disturbances at Earth. Collectively, these three phenomena (flare, prominence eruption, and CME) are referred to as a "solar eruption."

 

It is now widely accepted that solar eruptions are mainly due to a sudden and violent reconfiguration of  a portion of the coronal magnetic field, caused by a process called magnetic reconnection. When this happens, a significant fraction of the energy that is stored in the magnetic field is converted into other energy forms, such as thermal energy (which heats the plasma in the flare region), kinetic energy (which accelerates energetic particles), and bulk kinetic energy (which drives the CME). However, the details of this energy conversion process are not yet well understood. 

 

We addressed this important question using magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) numerical simulations of solar eruptions. In these simulations, first a model of the global corona is produced. Then, a magnetic flux rope (a twisted flux tube) is added to mimic the source region of an eruption (e.g., a sunspot region). Lastly, an eruption is initiated by increasing the magnetic energy of the flux rope beyond a critical value. As the eruption proceeds, the expanding flux rope evolves into a CME, while magnetic reconnection in a vertical current sheet that forms below the rising rope causes the flare. Numerical MHD studies of energy conversion during flare reconnection were done previously (e.g., the seminal work by Birn et al., 2009). However, the employed models were less realistic than ours, as they did not include a flux rope and the self-consistent formation of the flare current sheet. Moreover, we partially used a more complete description of the energy flow in the corona called "thermodynamic MHD," which incorporates the effects of thermal conduction, radiative cooling, and background heating of the corona. Below we highlight some of our main project tasks and results.

 

(1) Using a thermodynamic MHD simulation of a solar eruption, we analyzed in detail the plasma heating and evolution in the region of the current sheet during a flare. We found that in the early flare phase plasma heating occurs mainly via ohmic dissipation in the flare current sheet, while in the later flare phase adiabatic compression of the plasma due to reconnection jets (outflows) becomes the main contributor. We could also demonstrate that plasma is adiabatically heated above the flare loops during the eruption, which provides an explanation for the hot supra-arcade plasma sheets that are often observed during the decay phase of large solar flares. 

 

(2) We used different MHD simulations to analyze the energy conversion and transport processes during flares by measuring the electromagnetic energy flux, the enthalpy flux (i.e., the convective transport of thermal energy), and the bulk kinetic energy flux into and out of the reconnection region. Our analysis revealed some important differences to the results by Birn et al. For example, while those authors found significant plasma heating to occur only below the reconnection region, we found that strong heating also takes place above that region. Furthermore, in contrast to Birn et al., in our simulations the outgoing bulk kinetic energy flux typically exceeds the outgoing enthalpy flux, due to stronger reconnection outflows being present in our simulations. These differences underline the need for using realistic models when studying the physics of solar flares.          

  

(3) We developed two new techniques that facilitate the overall MHD modeling of solar eruptions. First, we established a method for slowly driving a flux rope towards eruption via a process we called "helicity pumping." The main advantage of this method is that, in contrast to other techniques such as boundary flows, it preserve the radial surface magnetic field (e.g., a measured magnetogram). Second, we derived a new method for decomposing observed photospheric magnetic fields. An important property of this method is that it allows one to determine the footprints and geometry of a coronal flux rope merely from photospheric measurements. We expect both application to be useful to the solar physics community.
